text:
Digging deeper into this with my hardware guy he reminded me that the Win 10
device was a completely new computer cloned from our default image. 
I was thinking it had been backed up and restored from a previous computer but
that was not the case. 
There indeed is a second SSD but it was simply removed from it’s original
computer and placed into the new computer as a secondary drive for extra
storage. 
So it would seem that the Recovery partition truly did not exist in the new
computer at any point thus the specific kb install would fail. 
As a few have said here, is the Recovery partition truly needed if you are
cloning systems? 
Thanks again everyone. 
Jim 
[cid:McAndrews-Logo_b981f23b-af61-4e79-9eb1-f721417fba3e.PNG]

Jim Boettger
Manager, Information Technology Group
McAndrews, Held & Malloy, Ltd.
500 W. Madison St., 34th floor | Chicago, IL 60661
P: 312-775-8000 

website

Digging deeper into this with my hardware guy he reminded me that the Win 10
device was a completely new computer cloned from our default image. 
I was thinking it had been backed up and restored from a previous computer but

There indeed is a second SSD but it was simply removed from it’s original
computer and placed into the new computer as a secondary drive for extra
storage. 
So it would seem that the Recovery partition truly did not exist in the new

As a few have said here, is the Recovery partition truly needed if you are
